metadata.sermon_start_end: Things happen very quickly and tersely in the Gospel of Mark. I. By verse 9 in Mark 1 Jesus has been baptized by John. No words were spoken by John. Jesus simply plunged into the Jordan River. It was, we are told, a baptism of “repentance for the forgiveness of sins.” [...] Now in Lent we take the plunge yet again. It is a plunge into a new vocation. He called it “good news.” He said, “Follow me.” He performed his new ministry of healing and then he invited his followers to do the same.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon identifies the specific pericope of Mark 1. However, it fails Dekker's test of finding what is 'NOWHERE else in the Bible.' Instead of mining the unique Marcan 'schizo' (tearing open) of the heavens, it treats the text as a general template for baptismal vocation. It drifts into 1 Peter 3 and Psalm 91, diluting the specificity of the Marcan text.
quotes: Things happen very quickly and tersely in the Gospel of Mark.
This may be an allusion to Psalm 91
In the strange epistle reading in 1 Peter 3...
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Focus exclusively on the Marcan urgency and the specific 'tearing' of the heavens to find a word that is unique to this Gospel's witness.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: There is a clear attempt at exposition regarding the 'Son' as a coronation title and the 'wild beasts' as a threat. The preacher understands the literary structure ('quickly and tersely'). However, the exegesis remains somewhat superficial, serving more as a springboard for the application rather than a deep dive into the Greek or the specific theological history of Israel.
quotes: The phrase 'You are my Son' is used for coronations when the old king empowered the new, young king.
Mark wants us to notice that this event was very special and inexplicable.
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Deepen the exploration of the 'wilderness' (eremos) in the context of Israel's history to ground the 'vocation' in more than just modern psychological purpose.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is frequent but tends toward the general truths Dekker forbids. Terms like 'healing, transformation, forgiveness' are abstract. While 'Wall Street' and 'racism' are mentioned, they are used as buzzwords rather than concrete applications of the specific text to the specific congregation's life.
quotes: The vocation of baptism calls us to do God's work in the world—work of healing, transformation, forgiveness, reconciliation.
Jerusalem was the center of the greed system, the combination of Wall Street and Main Street...
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Avoid listing general categories of 'good work' and instead describe one concrete, contemporary 'wild beast' that the congregation faces this week.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon follows a 'two-block' structure: Part I is Jesus (exposition), Part II is 'Us' (application). This is exactly what Dekker warns against. It makes the relevance of the text feel like a secondary 'imitation' rather than a single movement where the hearer is 'expounded' by the Word.
quotes: I imagine that what happened to Jesus in his baptism might be what happens to us in our baptism as well.
But of course the story does not linger too long over Jesus as such, but turns attention to his disciples...
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Collapse the distance between the Marcan text and the hearer. Do not treat Jesus' baptism as a 'model' but as a current event that involves the hearer immediately.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The sermon is heavily weighted toward 'vocation' (gratitude/sanctification) and 'wilderness' (misery), but it is too Christocentric in a way that Dekker warns against—it risks becoming objective. The 'misery' is externalized as 'the world' or 'greed' rather than the hearer's own misery before God.
quotes: It is, in sum, a world that contradicts the promise of the gospel...
The real discipline of Lent is to consider where the Spirit may propel us in our new vocation.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Internalize the 'misery.' Instead of 'the world's greed,' address the hearer's own lostness and need for the 'one Lord'.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The 'two ways' are largely absent. While 'being lost in time' is hinted at through the failure of vocation, there is no real sense of the 'broad way that leads to destruction.' The tone is too safe; the 'wild beasts' are mentioned but the ultimate stakes of human choice are softened by the 'angels' always being there.
quotes: ...finding in ways that we do not expect and cannot explain that gifts are given that keep us safe.
The company of Jesus counts on angels...
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Address the reality that one can indeed be 'lost'—that the choice to follow or not follow has eternal or at least definitive temporal consequences.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is the subject of the first half, but the sermon shifts toward the 'vocation' of the believer. Christ becomes a 'conduit' or 'agent' rather than the 'telos' who is God. The doctrine of the two natures is not felt; Jesus is more of a pioneer of a new lifestyle.
quotes: Jesus is given a peculiar vocation that the church celebrates. It is a calling to be God’s agent...
As the Spirit approved of Jesus... so in our baptism we have confidence that God celebrates us...
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Ensure Christ remains the 'telos' (goal) of the sermon, not just the 'example' for our own Lenten journey.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 1250 words, the sermon would take about 12-13 minutes. According to Dekker, this is insufficient for the 'breadth' required for 'depth.' The brevity contributes to the use of generalities rather than specific, concrete exposition and application.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Expand the sermon to at least 20 minutes by deepening the exegetical work and making the application more concrete and less categorical.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon falls short of Dekker’s criteria primarily due to its brevity and its 'two-block' structure which separates exposition from application. It relies on general theological categories (vocation, healing, greed) rather than the specific, unique word of the Marcan text. The seriousness of the 'two ways' is missing, replaced by a somewhat optimistic view of 'vocation' and 'angelic' protection.
strengths: Clear identification of the Marcan literary style ('quick and terse').
Effective use of the 'wilderness' as a zone of discomfort rather than just a place of quiet.
weaknesses: Insufficient length (approx. 12 minutes) prevents theological depth.
Separation of Jesus' story and the congregation's story into distinct sections.
Lack of concrete, specific application; reliance on general 'liberal' or 'orthodox' tropes about greed and racism.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is not a sermon in the sense of Dekker's definition. It is a thematic reflection on baptismal vocation using the text as an illustration rather than an actualization of the Word of God that finds what is unique to the passage.
